channel.title: EU Bans claim that water can prevent dehydration
channel.description:
http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/eu/8897662/EU-bans-claim-that-water-can-prevent-dehydration.html
EU officials concluded that, following a three-year investigation, there was no evidence to prove the previously undisputed fact. Producers of bottled water are now forbidden by law from making the claim and will face a two-year jail sentence if they defy the edict, which comes into force in the UK next month. Last night, critics claimed the EU was at odds with both science and common sense. Conservative MEP Roger Helmer said: “This is stupidity writ large. “The euro is burning, the EU is falling apart and yet here they are: highly-paid, highly-pensioned officials worrying about the obvious qualities of water and trying to deny us the right to say what is patently true. “If ever there were an episode which demonstrates the folly of the great European project then this is it.”
UROP

item.title: EU Bans claim that water can prevent dehydration
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Mopman: I’m not in favor of banning anything that works if it is regulated. New treatments should always be considered if it is better than normal medicine.

We have two different understanding of “alternative medicine”, and let us stop this discussion, as it goes way of the topic.

Read full topic
item.source: EU Bans claim that water can prevent dehydration

item.title: EU Bans claim that water can prevent dehydration
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

In that case I’d say we already have that - with organisations like the MHRA (Medicine Regulatory Board) and the ASA (Advertising Standards) in the UK, and equivalent organisations in other countries.

I do not agree that the definition of “alternative” excludes things that are proven to work, though, since as I said, many things that do work are considered “alternative”.

You also seemed above to be intending to ban these things altogether, rather than just control how they are portrayed in advertising and by the people who practice them, which is silly imo.

Read full topic
item.source: EU Bans claim that water can prevent dehydration

item.title: EU Bans claim that water can prevent dehydration
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Mopman:
“Alternative medicine is any healing practice, “that does not fall within the realm of conventional medicine.”[1] It is based on historical or cultural traditions, rather than on scientific evidence.”
By this definition from Wikipedia it excludes anything that is proven to work as “alternative”.
And it “alternative medicine” by this definition EU should ban “alternative” as a medicine.

It is like the water, you shouldn’t be allowed to claim something that isn’t true. I wonder if you were allowed to make that claim if you called the water “homeopathic”.

Read full topic
item.source: EU Bans claim that water can prevent dehydration

item.title: EU Bans claim that water can prevent dehydration
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

I’ll be honest, I don’t understand what comes under “alternative medicine” either. That’s one of my worries with people being up for “banning” it - who decides what is alternative and what isn’t?

Wikipedia lists Hypnotherapy, Herbal Therapy, Nutritional Supplements, Physical Exercise and plenty of other useful and effective treatments as “branches of alternative medicine”.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Alternative medicine is a term that sounds worse because it also contains quackery. I’m not familiar with the proportions though: I am prone to believe that alternative medicine mainly consists of quackery like homeopathy and faith healing and the like. I could be wrong though.

Read full topic

item.description:

item.source: EU Bans claim that water can prevent dehydration

item.title: EU Bans claim that water can prevent dehydration
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

A meeting of 21 scientists in Parma, Italy, concluded that reduced water content in the body was a symptom of dehydration and not something that drinking water could subsequently control.

[…]

Prof Brian Ratcliffe, spokesman for the Nutrition Society, said dehydration was usually caused by a clinical condition and that one could remain adequately hydrated without drinking water.
He said: “The EU is saying that this does not reduce the risk of dehydration and that is correct.
“This claim is trying to imply that there is something special about bottled water which is not a reasonable claim.”

If I read that correct, dehydration is a symptom, not a disease on its own. If that’s right, then the ban isn’t all that bad. They can still sell water, they just can’t claim that it is a cure for something. It would be similar to banning the claim that water cures cancer (an extreme example).

Last night, critics claimed the EU was at odds with both science and common sense. Conservative MEP Roger Helmer said: “This is stupidity writ large. “The euro is burning, the EU is falling apart and yet here they are: highly-paid, highly-pensioned officials worrying about the obvious qualities of water and trying to deny us the right to say what is patently true. “If ever there were an episode which demonstrates the folly of the great European project then this is it.”

This is just BS. The European Parliament isn’t the institution concerned with battling the current crisis, the European council is. Sure, they probably discuss measures, but the majority of decisions is made by the heads of state in their meetings. This is a common tactic among populists, they sketch a doom scenario which makes the MEP’s (he’s one of them!) look like fat old well payed nitpickers.

Read full topic
item.source: EU Bans claim that water can prevent dehydration

item.title: EU Bans claim that water can prevent dehydration
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

At which point you what? Unban it? Or it never gets studied, because as an “alternative medicine” it wasn’t worth the hassle to circumvent whatever legislation you introduce to try it.

You shouldn’t legislate against what people do with their own bodies, without harming anyone else. It’s bad enough that we do it anyway, its even worse that we do it to sick people who are trying to get better.

EDIT: Besides, it’s simply untrue that alternative medicine with proven efficacy becomes mainstream medicine. There are plenty of examples of things that have been proven to work, are used in medical settings and yet are still “fringe”. Hypnosis, for example.

Read full topic

Until they are proven to be effective of course.
“Alternative medicine” that works become just “medicine”.

item.source: EU Bans claim that water can prevent dehydration

item.title: EU Bans claim that water can prevent dehydration
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Although this is retarded… it’s not quite as retarded as it looks.

I mean, its pretty well known that water is not a cure for dehydration. True dehydration involves electrolyte imbalances too, and chugging pure water at that point is likely to make you a lot worse. Also, their issue was with the fact that water is no BETTER at preventing dehydration than any other drink. Everyone knows we have to drink - but it doesn’t matter what you drink, really.

But yes, it’s a stupid waste of time to discuss. The people who submitted it basically did it just to make a mockery of the system, though, so who’s the time waster here? The EU or the people who submitted the stupid request?

EDIT: As for “deny us our right” - whoever is quoted there apparently didn’t read the thing at all, since it specifically says that no action is required by member states.

Read full topic

item.title: EU Bans claim that water can prevent dehydration
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

Telegraph.co.uk

EU bans claim that water can prevent dehydration

Brussels bureaucrats were ridiculed yesterday after banning drink manufacturers from claiming that water can prevent dehydration.

EU officials concluded that, following a three-year investigation, there was no evidence to prove the previously undisputed fact. Producers of bottled water are now forbidden by law from making the claim and will face a two-year jail sentence if they defy the edict, which comes into force in the UK next month. Last night, critics claimed the EU was at odds with both science and common sense. Conservative MEP Roger Helmer said: “This is stupidity writ large. “The euro is burning, the EU is falling apart and yet here they are: highly-paid, highly-pensioned officials worrying about the obvious qualities of water and trying to deny us the right to say what is patently true. “If ever there were an episode which demonstrates the folly of the great European project then this is it.”

UROP
